text: Shortly after the discovery of <extra_id_0> APOBEC3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , it became clear that this human gene plays an important role in antiretroviral defense ( 4 ) .

Originally identified as a restriction factor of HIV-1 infection , expression of <extra_id_0> APOBEC3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was found in human peripheral blood lymphocytes and macrophages , which represent the main target cells for HIV-1 ( 32 ) .
In addition , the protein was detected in lung , liver , spleen , testis and ovary , but little is known about its transcriptional regulation ( 29 , 32 , 47 ) .
To address this question , we cloned the human <extra_id_0> APOBEC3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter and analyzed its regulation in T cells .
Applying 5'-RACE , we identified multiple start sites for transcription of the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .
This observation is consistent with the fact that the gene appears to lack canonical CCAAT and TATA boxes ( 32 ) , a condition often associated with multiple transcriptional start sites ( 49-51 ) .
However , one single start site was detected in 6 of 19 clones and was designated as +1 .
This TSS is located 66 bp upstream of the start of the published mRNA sequence ( GenBank ( TM ) NM021822 ) .
We cloned a 1025 bp promoter , which ranges from position -959 / +66 relative to the identified TSS .
<extra_id_0> Luciferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reporter assays showed that this promoter was transcriptionally active in A3.01 T cells .

Treatment with the phorbol ester TPA did not further enhance transcriptional activity , although upregulation of <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels in T cells by TPA has been described ( 33 ) .

text: Rose et al . used actinomycin D to block further transcription and did not find evidence for enhanced mRNA stability .
Therefore , the authors suggested that an enhanced transcription rate could be responsible for the increased amount of <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA after TPA treatment .

text: However , the promoter analysis we performed indicates a different mechanism that is independent of transcriptional regulation .

In addition , we observed that the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter was not inducible by <extra_id_0> IFN-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in A3.01 T cells , whereas in the hepatic cell line HepG2 , a moderate induction was measured .

text: It has been described previously that <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression is upregulated by interferons in hepatocytes and macrophages ( 46-48 , 52 ) .
In this context , two interferon - responsive elements have been identified at the positions -6 / +9 and +1 / +15 relative to the TSS ( 48 ) .
Consistent with this data , we observed an interferon induction in hepatocytes for the fragments ranging between 1025 and 120 bp length .
The activity of the 60 bp fragment that does not contain these motifs was not affected .
Thus , the induction we observed was most likely mediated by the described interferon-responsive elements .
However , according to our results , these motifs can enhance transcription in hepatic cells , but not in T cells .

This is surprising , since <extra_id_0> IFN-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - inducible signaling cascades are present in A3.01 T cells : we showed that the control plasmid harboring interferon - responsive GAS elements was markedly induced by <extra_id_0> IFN-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment .

In contrast , the GAS element was not responsive to <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment in these cells , suggesting that our T cell line was not able to mediate <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced signals .

So far , enhanced <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity by interferons is clearly described in hepatocytes and macrophages , whereas the situation in T cells is still unclear .

A recent study found no influence of <extra_id_0> IFN-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in resting primary blood lymphocytes ( 52 ) .

text: This observation is not contradictory to our results since T cell lines are mitotically active and therefore rather in an activated than in a resting state .

In conclusion , the current data suggests that regulation of the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity by interferons is dependent on the cell type and possibly also from the cellular activation status .
We additionally analyzed the influence of HIV-1 proteins on <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity .
The HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Vif <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein is neutralizing the antiviral function of <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by a multitude of ways .

Targeting the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein for proteasomal degradation is considered to be the main mode of action ( 37-41 ) , but it becomes more and more clear that other mechanisms are also involved .

There is evidence that <extra_id_0> Vif <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also promotes exclusion of <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from the virus particles and an influence on the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> translation process is discussed ( 8 , 42 , 43 ) .

The question whether <extra_id_0> Vif <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alters transcription controlled by the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter has not been analyzed so far .

text: Taken together , in T cell lines , the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter appears constitutively active .
By generating a series of 5 ' deletions , we showed that the core promoter is located within the region -114 / +66 relative to the TSS .

This 180 bp promoter was transcriptionally active in the lymphoid , myeloid and hepatic cell lines we tested , indicating that ubiquitous transcription factors are involved in regulation of <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene transcription .

text: A GC-box with the sequence TGGGCGGGAC was identified at position -87 / -78 of the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

This GC-box is essential for basal promoter activity , since changing the motif to <extra_id_0> TGTTCGGGAC <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by introducing two point mutations strongly reduced <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity .
The transcriptional potency of the GC-box was further demonstrated by cloning it upstream of an SV40 promoter .
This resulted in a 4-fold enhanced transcription rate .
The hypothesis that a general transcription factor is involved in regulation of <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription was confirmed by EMSA .

text: The Sp family of transcription factors is involved in transcriptional regulation of many housekeeping , tissue - specific , viral and inducible genes ( 57 ) .
Whereas <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> typically acts as an activator , <extra_id_0> Sp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can serve as a repressor or activator ( 57 ) .

However , in the context of the <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , both transcription factors serve as activators, as shown by siRNA - mediated silencing of the single factors .

Our results also provide information about the regulation of <extra_id_0> APOBEC3F <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> A3F <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , another member of the human APOBEC3 family .

text: The core promoter is located within a region of 180 bp at position -114 / +66 relative to the TSS .

A GC-box is crucial to the function of the core promoter and represents a binding site for <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Sp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription factors .

Our results can serve as a basis for future studies aimed at understanding how <extra_id_0> A3G <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> A3F <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is controlled in different tissues and how these restriction factors can be used to develop novel therapeutic strategies against HIV-1 infection .
